step.name: Find out the highest fare paid by women.
step.text: In the last tutorial, we learned how to import data into the RapidMiner repository, which is the central storage for all your data, models, and processes. In this tutorial, we will apply a filter to the Titanic data to only look at female passengers. Then, we can easily sort the data to find the highest ticket fares paid by women. You can then apply your new skills to answer the same question for men. Do you expect a difference for the passenger fare?

step.name: Get data into the workflow.

tasks.task: Drag the Titanic data from the Samples repository into the Process.

step.info: In RapidMiner, rows are called examples and data tables are called example sets. You'll find these terms throughout RapidMiner, so it is worth learning them right away.
There are many ways to find the highest fare paid for women. In this tutorial, you will remove men from the table or "filter examples out of the example set."

step.name: Set up filtering.
step.info: Only examples (rows) that meet the defined filter criteria - in this case women - stay in the example set. All other examples are removed.

tasks.task: Search for the Filter Examples operator using the search box at the top of the Operator panel. Drag Filter Examples into the Process panel.
Connect the output port of Retrieve Titanic with the input port of Filter Examples.
Click Filter Examples to select it, then click Add Filters in the Parameters panel to define a filter.
Select Sex on the left, equals in the middle, and type Female in the box on the right. Instead of typing, you can click on the magic wand and select Female from the list.

step.info: Whenever you add an operator to your process, you should immediately connect it. Remember that data flows between operators, so an operator's connection can influence its parameters. For example: How could the Filter operator "know" about the column Sex, if it is not connected to the data source?

step.name: Sort to show the highest fares first.

tasks.task: Search for and then drag the Sort operator into the Process.
Connect the output of Filter with the input of Sort.
Click on Sort to select it. Make the following changes in the Parameters panel:
Set attribute name to Passenger Fare.
Connect the Sort output port to the result port on the right of the Process panel.
16/media_play.pngRun the process and inspect the result.

step.info: Most operators have settings which define how the operators are working. You can find those on the right side of the Parameters panel, after you have selected an operator with a click.

step.name: Congratulations!
step.text: Well done! You can now see the highest fare paid for a woman on the Titanic: it's the first value in the column Passenger Fare.

questions.question: Can you change the process to see the highest fare paid by a man? Is it different than the highest fare paid by a woman?
